slides.title: Introduction to Managing Underwriting Authority
slides.notes: Introduction to the lesson and its importance in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to the lesson on managing underwriting authority within Guidewire PolicyCenter. This is a critical aspect of insurance operations, where we ensure that the right people have the right level of authority to make decisions on policies. Today, we'll explore the underlying data models, configuration points, and how these align with business needs. Understanding this will empower you to configure PolicyCenter effectively to support underwriting decisions.

slides.title: Understanding Underwriting Authority
slides.notes: Exploring the concept and importance of underwriting authority.
slides.narration: Underwriting authority in PolicyCenter is all about defining who can make what decisions. It's not just about setting limits; it involves configuring complex rules and authority profiles that align with business policies. As a developer, you'll interact with entities like UWIssue and AuthorityGrant, ensuring they reflect the organization's decision-making hierarchy. Let's dive deeper into how these elements work together.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

• Work with Underwriting Rules in the user
interface

• Describe and work with the Authority Grants
and Authority Profiles

slides.title: The Role of Underwriting Rules
slides.notes: How underwriting rules define the scope and conditions for underwriting issues.
slides.narration: Underwriting rules are the backbone of managing underwriting authority. In PolicyCenter, these rules define conditions under which certain underwriting issues arise and how they are managed. Developers must carefully configure these rules, ensuring they align with business logic and operational policies. Remember, the goal is to automate decision-making processes while allowing for human oversight where necessary.
slides.ocrText:
Marci
Configuration
Developer

».
4

How can we configure PolicyCenter to
raise underwriting issues?

slides.title: Components of Underwriting Rules
slides.originalNotes:
Underwriting rules
PolicyCenter uses the UW Rule to define the UW Issue Type and specify the conditions to raise the issue. Configuration users should create and manage the set of underwriting rules and their characteristics very carefully. Guidewire recommends that you do not remove underwriting rules once they have been deployed in a production system.

The Underwriting Rule Screen can be divided into several categories.
Fields related to defining the UW Rule (mostly on the Rule Details tab). It includes Name, Code, Description, Checking Set, Blocking Point, Enabled, Start and End Date.
Fields related to evaluating the UW Issue. It includes the Applicability section, Rule Context, Rule Condition and UW Issue Details.
Fields related to approving the UW Issue (mostly on the Advanced tab). It includes Auto- approvable, Default Edit Before Bind, Default Approval Blocking Point, Default Duration (Rule Details tab), Value Comparator, Value Formatter Type, Default Value Assignment Type and Default Value Offset Amount.

PolicyCenter uses underwriting rule values:
to check the condition and raise UW issue
for determining availability of the Approve button, indicating that you can approve a specific issue to the default level to initially set the userinterface for approvals that do not already have an approval present
as automated approvals for auto-approvable issues and issues in automated processes

as automated approvals for auto-approvable issues and issues in automated processes
slides.narration: Underwriting rules in PolicyCenter are structured into several key components. The Rule Details tab helps define the rule, encompassing fields like Name, Code, and Blocking Point. Then there's the evaluation aspect, which includes the Rule Context and Conditions. Finally, approval mechanisms are configured on the Advanced tab. As you work with these components, think about how they integrate with the business's workflow and approval processes.
slides.ocrText:
Underwriting rules i

• An underwriting rule defines an underwriting issue
type, specifies when to check, and under what
conditions to raise an issue.

* In PolicyCenter, Go to Administration > Business
Rules > Underwriting Rules

« UW Rules can be edited, enabled / disabled by
authorized users

« UW Rules can be imported, exported and deployed
into different environment

slides.title: Configuring Underwriting Rules
slides.notes: Practical aspects of configuring underwriting rules.
slides.narration: Now that we've covered the theory, let's discuss the practical side of configuring underwriting rules. This involves working with the PolicyCenter UI and possibly extending functionality using Gosu scripts. The goal is to ensure that the rules are not only correctly defined but also effectively integrated with the rest of the system. Consider how these configurations affect real-time decision-making and automated processes.

slides.notes: Guide the viewer through the interface to view underwriting rules.
slides.narration: Take a moment to navigate to the Underwriting Rules section in PolicyCenter. Observe how rules are listed and categorized. Pay attention to the details—such as rule status and applicability—which can give you insights into how they function in the system. This is where you can see the direct impact of your configurations on the underwriting process.

slides.title: Managing Authority Profiles
slides.notes: Introduction to managing authority profiles and their importance.
slides.narration: Authority profiles are pivotal in defining what decisions an underwriter can make. Unlike roles, which are more static, authority profiles offer flexibility. They can be tailored to specific expertise or experience levels, such as underwriting for specific products or class codes. As a developer, you'll configure these profiles to ensure they align with both individual capability and organizational policy.

slides.title: Demo: Configuring Authority Profiles
slides.notes: Guide the viewer through the process of configuring authority profiles.
slides.narration: Let's explore the configuration of authority profiles. Navigate to the respective section in PolicyCenter and observe how profiles are structured. Notice the fields and options available for customization. This is where you can set the parameters that define an underwriter’s decision-making authority, ensuring they align with business needs and compliance requirements.

slides.title: Understanding Authority Grants
slides.notes: Explanation of authority grants and their significance.
slides.narration: Authority grants are the specific permissions associated with an underwriter's role. They dictate the boundaries of what decisions can be made without additional approval. Each grant correlates to an underwriting issue type, providing a structured approach to decision-making. Proper configuration of these grants ensures that underwriting processes are both efficient and compliant.
slides.ocrText:
Marci
Configuration
Developer

».
4

How can we set up users so they are
authorized to approve underwriting issues?

slides.title: Configuring Authority Grants and Profiles
slides.originalNotes:
Authority grants and authority profiles
Authority grants are similar to physical letters of authority. Each authority grant is based on an issue type defined in the underwriting rules. The authority grant can specify the values which need additional approval. Users can have zero or more Authority Profiles assigned to them. Authority profiles is different than a role. In the examples above, Job-level is the job grade a customer might have. In the base application the job-levels are Underwriter 1, Underwriter 2, and so on. When an underwriter has a specific expertise such as knowledge about Farm Equipment one can assign authority grants related to specific class codes and create a profile with those grants. Incremental, •Joe's Special" — bumps Joe's authority up a bit, since he isn't quite ready for a promotion to "Underwriter 2", meaning that the person has all the grants for "Underwriter 1" and some additional grants but not all the grants that he needs to be at ZI-Jnderwriter 2" level.
slides.notes:
Authority grants and authority profiles
Authority grants are similar to physical letters of authority. Each authority grant is based on an issue type defined in the underwriting rules. The authority grant can specify the values which need additional approval. Users can have zero or more Authority Profiles assigned to them. Authority profiles is different than a role. In the examples above, Job-level is the job grade a customer might have. In the base application the job-levels are Underwriter 1, Underwriter 2, and so on. When an underwriter has a specific expertise such as knowledge about Farm Equipment one can assign authority grants related to specific class codes and create a profile with those grants. Incremental, •Joe's Special" — bumps Joe's authority up a bit, since he isn't quite ready for a promotion to "Underwriter 2", meaning that the person has all the grants for "Underwriter 1" and some additional grants but not all the grants that he needs to be at ZI-Jnderwriter 2" level.
slides.narration: Authority grants function like letters of authority, each linked to specific underwriting issues. They are flexible, enabling customization for different levels of expertise. For example, you might have a profile that grants additional authority to an underwriter with specialized knowledge in certain areas. This ensures that authority aligns with both capability and business needs, promoting efficient decision-making.
slides.ocrText:
| Authority grants and authority profiles

• An Authority grant allows users to approve a specific issue
« Underwriting issue types with values can have a limit or “any” for approval
« Authority grants are added to authority profiles

• An Authority profile determine the types of underwriting issues that a user can
approve
« Authority profiles often contain multiple authority grants
* Multiple profiles allow fine-grained control
+ transaction-level, “Underwriter 1”
+ Expertise, “Farm Equipment”

+ Incremental, “Joe’s Special”

slides.title: The Process of Deploying Underwriting Rules
slides.notes: Steps and considerations for deploying underwriting rules.
slides.narration: Deploying underwriting rules is a strategic process. Ideally, these rules are developed and rigorously tested in a non-production environment. This allows for thorough evaluation and adjustment before they go live. While on-the-fly adjustments might be possible in production, it's best practice to ensure that any new rules are fully vetted to avoid unintended consequences.

slides.title: The Underwriting Rule Life Cycle
slides.notes: Description of the underwriting rule life cycle from draft to production.
slides.narration: The life cycle of an underwriting rule begins in the Draft status on a development server. Once a rule is tested and refined, it's promoted to Staged, ready for further testing. This structured approach ensures that rules are only moved to production once they meet all necessary criteria, thus minimizing risks and maintaining system integrity.
slides.ocrText:
Marci
Configuration
Developer

After | developed the underwriting rules,
how do | deploy it to production?

slides.title: Exporting and Importing Underwriting Rules
slides.originalNotes:
Deploying underwriting rules
Underwriting rules should be created and tested in a development environment. In that environment the rules can be tested and modified as necessary to get the expected results. This is the suggested method of creating underwriting rules. In extreme circumstances you can create rules on the fly in productiom However, you will generally want to use a development server for rule creation and testing. When the rules are tested and approved, you can migrate them to the production environment.
slides.notes:
Deploying underwriting rules
Underwriting rules should be created and tested in a development environment. In that environment the rules can be tested and modified as necessary to get the expected results. This is the suggested method of creating underwriting rules. In extreme circumstances you can create rules on the fly in productiom However, you will generally want to use a development server for rule creation and testing. When the rules are tested and approved, you can migrate them to the production environment.
slides.narration: Exporting and importing underwriting rules involve careful coordination. On the development server, you can export rules in the Staged status, ensuring they're ready for use. The exported file can then be imported into a production server, facilitating a smooth transition. This methodical process ensures that rules are consistently applied across environments.

| Deploying underwriting rules fa

* Create and test in a development environment, then deploy to the production
environment

• Useful for urgent situations like catastrophe management

slides.title: Demo: Exporting Underwriting Rules
slides.originalNotes:
Underwriting rule life cycle
On the development server, the initial status of a rule is Draft. After the rule is tested and approved, you set the status to Staged by clicking the Promote to Stage button on the Edit rule page.
Once a rule is in Staged status, it can be exported from the development server to the testing environment After it is fully tested, you can set the status to Approved so that it can be imported into the production server.
slides.notes:
Underwriting rule life cycle
On the development server, the initial status of a rule is Draft. After the rule is tested and approved, you set the status to Staged by clicking the Promote to Stage button on the Edit rule page.
Once a rule is in Staged status, it can be exported from the development server to the testing environment After it is fully tested, you can set the status to Approved so that it can be imported into the production server.
slides.narration: Let's go through the process of exporting underwriting rules. Locate the Underwriting Rules page and select a rule with the status of Staged. Follow the prompts to export the rule, noting the progress indicator. Once complete, you’ll have a file ready to be imported into another environment, ensuring continuity and consistency in rule application.

slides.title: Summary of Underwriting Authority Management
slides.originalNotes:
Exporting and importing rules
On both development and production servers, you import and export rules from the Underwriting Rules page. On the development server, you can only export rules that have a status of Staged. Once the export is complete, indicated by the Progress showing at 100%, you can download the file.

You can then import that file into either the development or production server depending on which direction you are going.
slides.notes:
Exporting and importing rules
On both development and production servers, you import and export rules from the Underwriting Rules page. On the development server, you can only export rules that have a status of Staged. Once the export is complete, indicated by the Progress showing at 100%, you can download the file.

You can then import that file into either the development or production server depending on which direction you are going.
slides.narration: Today, we covered the essentials of managing underwriting authority in PolicyCenter. From rules to authority profiles, these elements ensure that underwriting decisions are made efficiently and accurately. As you implement these concepts, remember to align them with your organization's business objectives. In our next lesson, we'll delve into the Product Model and policy lines, expanding your understanding of how PolicyCenter supports complex insurance products.

slides.title: Closing Thoughts
slides.notes: Reflect on the importance of underwriting authority management.
slides.narration: Managing underwriting authority is crucial for maintaining efficiency and compliance in insurance operations. By effectively configuring rules and authority profiles, you ensure that decision-making processes are both robust and adaptable. As you apply these concepts, consider their impact on business outcomes and customer experience.
